subject: Re: [junit] addon and wrappers...
msgSnippet: ... I don t see why you would need a wrapper for JUnit tests (for other, more risky libraries, I understand, for JUnit I don t see the reason). If it s for a
messageBody:
> Our products will JUnit, with an abstract wrapper for easy
> maintaineance and migration in the future...

I don't see why you would need a wrapper for JUnit tests (for other,
more risky libraries, I understand, for JUnit I don't see the reason).
If it's for a potential migration in the future, chances are that the
new framework will be totally different, so you're wrapping won't help
you much. But I'm not your CTO and you certainly have good reasons. I
am just curious.

> addon Assert classes, so the question is, if I have a MyAssert to
> extend junitx.framework.Assert, then I don't need a separate
> MyAssert2 to extend extend junit.framework.Assert, correct?

since junitx.framework.Assert extends junit.framework.Assert, you don't
need a MyAssert2.

> Also, I also like to use the functionalities in ObjectAssert,
> ArrayAssert, etc...but to do that I need to extend each class
> separately... Can you just put all those assert* methods in different
> classes in the same Assert class for convenient inheritance?

short answer: no I won't

long answer: JUnit-addons was always meant to be an addon to JUnit and
not to replace it. I only have an Assert class because I've written the
opposite assertions found in the standard JUnit Assert class.

And why not putting everything into one single Assert class? In the
future assert classes may depend on external jars and if all assert
methods were in the same Assert class, I would force everyone to be
dependant on these jars. This is not what I want to do. The solution
could be to have exceptions to the rule (one Assert class, other classes
for external dependencies) but this is messy in the long term. So no, I
won't.

-Vladimir
